The assessment of transport innovations and their mitigation potentials is at the core of how this chapter

options and social changes are now converging and how, in combination, they may have potenti

they both will need demand and efficiency changes to ensure they are equitable and inclusive.
he transformation of transport through examining systemic changes that
technological innovations in vehicles and fuels. The next three sections (10.4, 10.5, and 10.6) examine

assessed in a range of integrated modelling and sectoral transport scenarios;
10.8 sets out what would be needed for the most transformative scenario that can manage to achieve
the broad goals set out in Chapter 3 and the transport goals
Systemic changes in the transport sector
Systemic change is the emergence of new organisational patterns that affect the structure of a system.
While much attention has been given to engine and fuel technologies to mitigate
the transport sector, population dynamics, finance and
economic systems, urban form, culture, and
policy also drive emissions from the sector. Thus, systemic change requires innovations in these
components. These systemic changes offer the opportunity to decouple transport emissions from
urn, such decoupling allows environmental improvements like reduced GHG
emissions without loss of economic activity
There is evidence that suggests decoupling of transport emissions and economic growth is already
happening in developed and developing countries. Europe and China have shown the most dramatic
(Huizenga et al. 2015; Gao and Newman 2018; SLoCaT 2018b)
A continued and accelerated decoupling of the growth of
sions from economic growth is crucial for meeting the
